document_title: Metabolomic Profiling of the Secretome from Human Neural Stem Cells Flown into Space
summary_full: This study investigated the metabolic changes in human neural stem cells (NSCs) exposed to microgravity (ÂµG) during a spaceflight to the International Space Station (ISS). After 3 days in space, the secretome of NSCs revealed increased glycolysis, evidenced by elevated pyruvate and glycerate levels. The cells also showed activated catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) and glutamine, suggesting increased energy demands. Furthermore, space-flown NSCs (SPC-NSCs) exhibited enhanced NADH synthesis and spermidine production compared to ground controls (GC-NSCs). These findings indicate that the space environment triggers adaptive responses in NSCs, primarily by increasing energy production through enhanced glycolysis and amino acid catabolism to meet the demands of microgravity.
key_findings: Microgravity increases glycolysis in human neural stem cells, indicated by elevated pyruvate and glycerate levels.
Catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) and glutamine is activated in space-flown NSCs, suggesting increased energy production.
Space-flown NSCs show increased synthesis of NADH, a key molecule in energy metabolism.
The polyamine spermidine is significantly increased in the secretome of NSCs exposed to microgravity.
Metabolomic analysis revealed distinct biochemical profiles between space-flown and ground-control NSCs.
future_research_fields: Investigate the role of spermidine in NSC adaptation to microgravity and its potential link to autophagy.
Elucidate the synergistic effects of microgravity and ionizing radiation on NSC metabolism and function.
Conduct longer-duration spaceflights to observe the long-term adaptive mechanisms of NSCs.
Explore the therapeutic potential of modulating metabolic pathways in NSCs for space travel and neurological disorders.
Develop a 1G control onboard the ISS to better isolate the effects of microgravity from other spaceflight stressors.

conclusions: Microgravity induces a significant stress response in human neural stem cells, leading to increased energy production through enhanced glycolysis and amino acid catabolism. The observed increase in NADH synthesis and spermidine production suggests adaptive mechanisms to cope with the space environment. These findings have implications for maintaining CNS homeostasis during long-duration space missions and highlight the need for further research into NSC behavior in space.
impact_statement: This study reveals how microgravity alters the metabolism of human neural stem cells, providing crucial insights into cellular adaptation for future space exploration and potential applications in regenerative medicine.
